message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest the patient is suffering from pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune disease that causes blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. The disease is caused by IgG antibodies against desmoglein-3, a transmembrane protein that helps bind neighboring epidermal cells together. Therefore, (D) is the correct answer. Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomes are seen in pemphigoid, exotoxins destroying keratinocyte attachments are seen in Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, and IgA antibodies depositing in the dermal papillae are seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient's symptoms, along with the formation of new blisters upon manual rubbing, suggests the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune disorder that involves IgG antibodies against desmosomes, which are transmembrane proteins that connect cells. Therefore, choice (D) is the correct answer. The other options are not associated with pemphigus vulgaris.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest the patient has pemphigus vulgaris, which is caused by autoantibodies against desmoglein proteins, which are transmembrane proteins between cells in the skin. Therefore, the most likely answer is option (D). Option (A) is seen in pemphigoid, option (B) is seen in toxic epidermal necrolysis, and option (C) is seen in dermatitis herpetiformis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of flaccid bullae filled with serous fluid, with no surrounding erythema, and formation of new blisters with manual rubbing of the skin suggest pemphigus vulgaris. It is caused by IgG antibodies attacking transmembrane proteins between cells. Option A is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, Option B is characteristic of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, and Option C is characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the bullae that appear flaccid and filled with serous fluid and new blisters forming within minutes upon rubbing the skin, suggest pemphigus vulgaris. This disease is caused by IgG antibodies attacking the desmoglein proteins that connect skin cells together, resulting in the formation of blisters. Therefore, the correct answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the development of blisters suggest the disease is pemphigus vulgaris. Among the options, only IgG antibodies against desmogleins, transmembrane proteins that hold keratinocytes together, are involved in the pathogenesis of pemphigus vulgaris. Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomes are involved in bullous pemphigoid, exotoxin destroying keratinocyte attachments cause toxic epidermal necrosis, and IgA antibodies depositing in dermal papillae cause dermatitis herpetiformis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and bullae suggest the patient has pemphigus vulgaris. Among the options, only option D involves antibodies against transmembrane proteins between cells, which is relevant for pemphigus vulgaris pathogenesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including blisters that form upon rubbing, suggest the patient has pemphigus vulgaris. This disease is caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins, which are transmembrane proteins that facilitate cell-cell adhesion in the skin. IgG is the class of antibody involved in this pathogenesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam suggest the patient has pemphigus vulgaris, which is caused by autoantibodies against desmoglein-3, a transmembrane protein between keratinocytes. Therefore, the correct answer is IgG against transmembrane proteins between cells. Option A is true for bullous pemphigoid, option B is true for staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, and option C is true for dermatitis herpetiformis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris. Among the options, only IgG antibodies against desmoglein, a transmembrane protein between cells, is involved in the pathogenesis of pemphigus vulgaris.
